modules.title: Market and Economic Fundamentals
topics: Meaning and types of market: Perfect Competition, Monopoly, Monopolistic and Oligopoly markets
Basic concepts of economics – needs, wants, and utility
National Income: GDP and GNP
Demand and Supply, Law of Demand, and the role of demand and supply in price determination
Price Elasticity and its importance in economics
Inflation: meaning, causes, and economic implications

modules.title: Business and Banking
topics: Types of business organizations: Proprietorship, Partnership, Joint-stock company, and Cooperative society – characteristics and comparison
Banking system: role of commercial banks and importance of credit in industrial functioning
Role of the Central Bank: Reserve Bank of India – functions and monetary control
International Business and Trade Environment: significance and challenges

modules.title: Financial Accounting
topics: Fundamentals of accounting: Journals, Ledgers, Trial Balance, Profit & Loss Account, and Balance Sheet
Financial statement analysis using ratio analysis and cash flow analysis
Interpretation of financial performance and implications for managerial decisions

modules.title: Cost Accounting and Decision Making
topics: Cost accounting terminology: fixed, variable, and semi-variable costs
Break-even analysis and cost-volume-profit relationships
Preparation of cost sheet and its interpretation
Budgeting and variance analysis for managerial control
Marginal cost-based decision making

modules.title: Time Value of Money and Capital Concepts
topics: Time value of money: present value, future value, annuity, and perpetuity
Concept of equity and debt financing
Cost of capital and its relevance in investment decisions

modules.title: Capital Budgeting and Project Evaluation
topics: Methods of project appraisal: average rate of return, payback period, discounted cash flow methods
Net present value (NPV), benefit-cost ratio (BCR), and internal rate of return (IRR)
Depreciation concepts and types of depreciation methods
Replacement and sensitivity analysis for investment decisions

books: R. Narayanswami, “Financial Accounting - A Managerial Perspective”, Prentice-Hall of India Private Limited, New Delhi.
James C. Van Horne, “Fundamentals of Financial Management”, Prentice-Hall of India Private Limited, New Delhi.
H. L. Ahuja, “Modern Economic Theory”, S. Chand, New Delhi.
Donald G. Newman, Ted G. Eschenbach, and Jerome P. Lavelle, “Engineering Economic Analysis”, Oxford University Press, New York, 2012.
courseOutcomes: Evaluate a project and estimate its total cost
Apply financial analytical methodologies to assess organizational performance
Participate actively in the capital budgeting process of an organization
Provide insights for product pricing decisions
Understand the interplay of economic variables and indicators in professional contexts
Apply accounting concepts related to costs, revenues, assets, liabilities, capital, profit, investment, and interest

modules.title: Number Systems, Boolean Algebra and Logic Gates
topics: Data and number systems: binary, octal, and hexadecimal representation and conversions
BCD, Gray code, Excess-3 code and conversions between them
Signed binary number representation using 1’s and 2’s complement methods
Binary arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, etc.
Boolean algebra and De-Morgan’s theorem
Logic gates: AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR, XNOR – truth tables and circuit representation
Universal logic gates and their implementations
Sum of Products (SOP) and Product of Sums (POS) forms
Minimization of logic expressions using algebraic, Karnaugh map, and Quine-McCluskey methods

modules.title: Arithmetic and Combinational Circuits
topics: Arithmetic circuits: ripple carry adder, carry look-ahead adder (CLA), carry save adder (CSA), and BCD adder
Subtractor circuit design and implementation
Combinational circuits: encoder, decoder, comparator, multiplexer, demultiplexer, and parity generator
Shannon’s expansion theorem and realization of logic functions using multiplexers
Parity generator design and applications

modules.title: Sequential Logic Circuits
topics: Basic memory elements and flip-flops: SR, JK, D, and T flip-flops
Sequential circuit design methodology: state tables and state diagrams
State reduction method and circuit excitation/output tables
Derivation of Boolean functions for sequential circuits
Finite State Machine (FSM) design using sequential circuit methodology
Registers: parallel load registers, shift registers and their types
Counters: asynchronous (ripple) and synchronous (binary, BCD, Johnson) counters

modules.title: Memory Systems and Logic Families
topics: Memory systems: basic concepts and designs of RAM (SRAM and DRAM), ROM, EPROM, and EEPROM
Programmable logic devices: PLA, PAL, PLD, and gate arrays
Logic families: NMOS and CMOS – operation, characteristics, and specifications
Realization of basic logic gates using NMOS and CMOS technologies
Open collector and tri-state gates, wired-AND connections, and bus operations

textBooks: Morris M. Mano, “Digital Logic and Computer Design”, PHI.
Leach & Malvino, “Digital Principles & Applications”, 5th Edition, McGraw Hill.
R. P. Jain, “Modern Digital Electronics”, 2nd Edition, Tata McGraw Hill.
Brian Holdsworth & Clive Woods, “Digital Logic Design”, 4th Edition.
H. Taub & D. Schilling, “Digital Integrated Electronics”, McGraw Hill.
referenceBooks: John F. Wakerly, “Digital Design: Principles and Practices”.
A. Anand Kumar, “Fundamentals of Digital Circuits”, PHI.
courseOutcomes: Learn binary number systems and design logic circuits using combinational gates
Design applications of sequential circuits
Design and analyze finite state machines (FSMs)
Understand memory classification and types
Learn the basics of CMOS logic
Understand the design of various digital components used in VLSI applications

modules.title: Linear Data Structure I
topics: Introduction to data structures: concepts of data and data structures, Abstract Data Type (ADT) and Data Type
Algorithms and programs: basic idea of pseudo-code and its role in data structures
Introduction to time and space complexity analysis of algorithms
Arrays: representation in memory – row major and column major order
Sparse matrix representation and applications
Array representation of polynomials
Linked lists: singly, circular, and doubly linked lists
Linked list representation of polynomial and its applications

modules.title: Linear Data Structure II
topics: Stack: definition and implementation using arrays and linked lists
Principles of recursion and applications of stack in recursion
Differences between recursion and iteration, tail recursion concepts
Queue: definition, types (linear, circular, deque), and their implementations using arrays and linked lists
Implementation of deque with input and output restrictions
Applications of queue and deque in real-world problems

modules.title: Non-Linear Data Structures
topics: Trees: basic terminologies and representations (using arrays and linked lists)
Binary trees and traversal techniques: preorder, inorder, and postorder traversals
Threaded binary trees: left, right, and full threaded structures
Binary search trees: creation, insertion, deletion, and searching operations
Height-balanced binary trees (AVL trees): insertion and deletion with examples
B-Trees: insertion and deletion operations with examples
Graphs: definitions, basic concepts, and representations (adjacency matrix and adjacency list)
Graph traversal algorithms: Depth First Search (DFS) and Breadth First Search (BFS)
Graph connectivity concepts and applications

modules.title: Searching, Sorting and Hashing
topics: Sorting algorithms: bubble sort (and its optimization), insertion sort, shell sort, selection sort, merge sort, quick sort, heap sort, and radix sort
Complexity analysis of sorting algorithms
Searching techniques: sequential search, binary search, and interpolation search
Hashing concepts and functions
Collision resolution techniques in hashing: open hashing and closed hashing

textBooks: Reema Thareja, “Data Structures using C”, Oxford University Press.
Narasimha Karumanchi, “Data Structures and Algorithms Made Easy”, CareerMonk Publications.
referenceBooks: Narasimha Karumanchi, “Data Structures and Algorithms Made Easy - Data Structures and Algorithmic Puzzles”, CareerMonk Publications.
Ellis Horowitz, Sartaj Sahni, Susan Anderson, “Fundamentals of Data Structures in C”, Freed.
Aaron M. Tenenbaum, “Data Structures in C”.
Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, Clifford Stein, “Introduction to Algorithms”, The MIT Press.
courseOutcomes: Demonstrate the standard data structures covered in this course in relevant applications.
Identify the applications of ordered and unordered lists in data structure problems.
Apply stack and queue data structures to solve mathematical and real-life problems.
Explore tree and graph approaches to solve given problem definitions.
Analyze sorting, searching, and hashing algorithms covered in this course in related applications.
Compare the performance and efficiency of alternative data structure implementations.

modules.title: Human Society and the Value System
topics: Values: definition, importance, and application
Formation of values: process of socialization, development of self and integrated personality, morality, courage, integrity
Types of values and their importance:
Social values: justice, rule of law, democracy, Indian Constitution, secularism
Aesthetic values: perception and appreciation of beauty
Organizational values: employee–employer rights, relationships, and obligations
Psychological values: integrated personality and mental health
Spiritual values and their role in everyday life
Value spectrum for a good life and meaning of a good life
Value crisis in contemporary society – individual, societal, and cultural levels
Value crisis management – strategies and case studies

modules.title: Ethics, Professional Ethics, and Work Ethics
topics: Ethics and ethical values: principles and theories of ethics
Consequential and non-consequential ethics: egotism, utilitarianism, Kant’s theory, ethics of care, justice, fairness, rights, and duties
Standardization, codification, acceptance, and application of ethics
Types of ethics: ethics of rights and duties, ethics of responsibility, ethics and moral judgment, ethics of care, ethics of justice and fairness
Work ethics and quality of life at work
Professional ethics in engineering: moral issues and dilemmas, moral autonomy, and types of inquiry
Kohlberg’s theory and Gilligan’s theory (consensus and controversy)
Code of professional ethics: ASME, ASCE, IEEE, Institute of Engineers, IIMM, IETE
Violations of code of ethics – conflict, causes, and consequences
Engineering as social experimentation; engineers as responsible experimenters (computer ethics, weapons development)
Engineers as managers, consultants, experts, witnesses, advisors, and moral leaders
Conflict between business demands and professional ideals
Social and ethical responsibilities of technologists
Whistle blowing: facts, contexts, justifications, and case studies
Ethics and industrial law
Institutionalizing ethics: relevance, application, digression, and consequences

modules.title: Science, Technology and Engineering Ethics
topics: Science, technology, and engineering as knowledge and profession – definition, nature, social function, and practical application
Rapid industrial growth and its consequences
Renewable and non-renewable resources: definitions and types
Energy crisis and its impact on development
Industry and industrialization – man–machine interaction
Impact of assembly line and automation on society
Technology assessment and impact analysis
Industrial hazards and safety principles
Safety regulations, safety engineering, and professional responsibilities
Safety and risk – risk-benefit analysis and risk reduction strategies
Technology transfer: definition, types, and relevance in Indian context

modules.title: Environment and Eco-friendly Technology
topics: Human development and environmental balance
Ecological and environmental ethics
Depletion of natural resources and environmental degradation
Pollution and pollution control mechanisms
Eco-friendly technologies: implementation, impact, and assessment
Sustainable development: definition, concepts, and strategies
Modern trends in sustainable development
Appropriate technology movement by Schumacher and later developments
Reports and findings of the Club of Rome on global sustainability

books: A. N. Tripathi, “Human Values”, New Age International, New Delhi, 2006.
George Ritzer, “Classical Sociological Theory”, The McGraw Hill Companies, New York, 1996.
S. L. Doshi, “Postmodern Perspectives on Indian Society”, Rawat Publications, New Delhi, 2008.
D. K. Bhatnagar, “Sustainable Development”, Cyber Tech Publications, New Delhi, 2008.
Ray Kurzwell, “The Age of Spiritual Machines”, Penguin Books, New Delhi, 1999.
S. K. Weinberg, “Social Problems in Modern Urban Society”, Prentice Hall Inc., USA, 1970.
Anthony Giddens, “Sociology”, 13th Edition, Polity Press, London, 2009.
courseOutcomes: Be aware of the value system and understand its importance in the workplace.
Apply ethical theories in the decision-making process.
Follow institutional and organizational ethical codes of conduct.
Implement the principles governing work ethics in professional life.
Develop strategies to implement sustainable development models.
Apply ecological ethics and promote eco-friendly technologies where relevant.
